snippet: Mary T. Barra, barely two months into her job as G.M.’s chief executive, pledged to fix faulty ignition switches linked to 12 deaths and sought to restore some measure of confidence.
abstract: Mary T Barra, barely two months into her job as General Motors chief executive, pledges to fix faulty ignition switches linked to 12 deaths and to explain why GM failed for 10 years to correct problem it knew existed; seeks to restore some measure of confidence in the company's new leadership, starting with herself.

byline.contributor: Hilary Stout contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: Mary T. Barra, barely two months into her job as G.M.’s chief executive, pledged to fix faulty ignition switches linked to 12 deaths and sought to restore some measure of confidence.

headline.main: G.M. Chief Steps Up to Handle Safety Questions
headline.print_headline: New G.M. Chief Stepping Up to Handle Safety Questions
